characters: BARON AND FLAEMMCHEN ON DANCE FLOOR

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE ROOM
dialogues.text: It is the first time we have seen it. There are about eig girls very busy. Morning confusion. (parts to be written) We pick up essential lines as we PAN DOWN SHOOTING AT THE GIRL'S FACES, assuming the CAMERA to be the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand Hotel -- good morning -- no,  Baron von Gaigern's room does not  answer... Yes,... all right... Baron  von Gaigern's chauffeur calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, nine-thirty Doctor  Otternschlag... No, Doctor, no  messages... No, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand Hotel -- good morning... who  is calling Madam Grusinskaya?... Oh,  Mr. Pimenov. Madam Grusinskaya is  not to be disturbed, sir... no, sir...  yes, sir --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word passes down repeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Preysing's calls to one sixty  two for today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- good morning... Mr. Preysing -- (she plugs through)

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Telephone bell ringing. General shot. Gerstenkorn, an old business man and Doctor Waitz, counse for the Saxonia organization are sitting at a gree table, smoking and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at watch) Nine-thirty, Mr. Preysing keeps us  waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has returned) He likes to play the great man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at market  report from table) The Preysing stock is holding its  own today on the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask Preysing what it's costing him  to keep it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ask me what it's costing us to  hammer it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Preysing people get the  Manchester contract, we shall  certainly merge with the Preysing  company -- but if they haven't they're  ruined -- Preysing will have to  declare himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh -- here he is now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Flaemmchen enters. She is agreeably  surprised to see the room full of men. She likes men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beams) Good morning, gentlemen -- Mr.  Preysing will be here in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business of Schweimann and Flaemmchen. Gerstenkorn, making notes, glances at his watch again. Door opens suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enters) Good morning, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late, I've been waiting  for Justice Zinnowitz, my legal  advisor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- ho -- you want legal aid against  us? -- The whole thing seems to me  to be very simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very simple -- I've always liked the  way you dressed, Preysing -- English,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disturbed) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) They turn out marvelous material in  Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manchester -- yes. Yes, yes, they  do. Yes -- Now gentlemen shall we  begin at the beginning? -- Have we  cigars -- water and everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen, who has been busy preparing her little table work is seen in several CLOSEUPS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a wink to  Gerstenkorn) Manchester is a very interesting  city, don't you think so, Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stalling) Manchester -- yes -- yes. A man in  the textile industry naturally has  to know Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of business to be done  with the Manchester Cotton Company.  They've the whole English market  right in their hands. Have you any  connections with -- Manchester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) We have a good many connections in  England, naturally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean with the Manchester people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Gerstenkorn  impudently) We are here to discuss our merger.  Naturally I can make no statement at  this time. We must begin at the  beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winking at Schweimann) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (far-away commencing  to read his report) Since, on the eleventh of June, this  year -- when the first negotiations  for a merger between our respective  firms was entered into -- both parties  have fully agreed that this merger  can result only in mutual advantages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT this speech, which if played by Beery will be  interesting, with signals, winks and signs between the ot three men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- yes -- I beg your pardon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm laying before you the last general  statement of our concern. Active  capital, plant and machinery, raw  material and finished product -- for  instance -- mop rags --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mop rags --!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business between Preysing and Flaemmchen finding papers o 'Mop Rag' report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we want to know about is  Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Preysing -- that's what we  want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to wait for Justice  Zinnowitz, before I commit myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Preysing, Preysing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No water -- What a place!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do is phone for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen, who is on her toes and busy every minute, rus to the telephone and gives an order -- her conversation i heard over the conversation of the men in the room -- CAM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water -- seltzer, three or four  bottles and cigars -- good ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see this session is going to  be exhaustive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now to proceed with the projected  merger, the advantages for the Saxonia  are so obvious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- now let's talk like adults.  You want to tell us now a along story  of what your factory can do. We know  all that you could tell us and if  you tell the truth it wouldn't sound  so good. When you first approached  us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did not approach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly looking  through the papers) Letter on file September fourteenth  would show that you approached...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching the document  from his hand --  losing his temper) It isn't so -- this was a response  to a tentative feeler of your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching the document  violently away) Tentative my foot -- a month before  this your old father-in-law came  very privately and scratched at my  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scratched -- (he nearly chokes) We did not take the initiative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you took the initiative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zinnowitz enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, gentlemen -- I see the  conference is already underway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, here you are, Justice Zinnowitz --  I'm at cross-purposes with these  gentlemen -- will you clear up the  situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the situation is perfectly clear,  If you will allow me -- (he clears his throat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How clear is Manchester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foggy -- frightfully foggy, always,  I'm told. (to Preysing) Have you said anything about  Manchester, Mr. Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can make no statement about  Manchester at this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is dead silence for a moment -- he clears his throa commences in almost the same tone as Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since, on the eleventh of June of  this year -- when the first  negotiations for a merger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over Zinnowitz's  voice -- with a sigh --  sits back) Thank God we're beginning at the  beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops suddenly --  takes glasses from  his nose -- he is  speaking, not reading) As you remember it -- when you  approached us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bangs the paper down) We did not approach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you did -- I said you did --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I said we didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know we didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During all this commotion Flaemmchen is paying no attenti whatsoever. She is calmly spraying herself with a perfume atomizer and smiling at a gentleman. The noise continues  over her.

dialogues.speaker: NO SCENE 61
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: The atmosphere has changed, the sun shines. Grusinskaya i reclining on the chaise-lounge -- her Chinese robe drawn  about her. She speaks voluably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- I was ambitious then -- ambition  was in my blood -- no rest, no  stopping. We were drilled like little  soldiers -- We danced in the school  of the Imperial Ballet, in St.  Petersburg. I was little and slim  but hard as diamond -- a duty machine --  No rest, no stopping. And then -- I  became famous and whoever is famous  is alone... But why should I be  telling you this? Last night I did  not know you at all -- who are you,  really? -- I do not even know your  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Felix Benvenuto von Gaigern. My  mother called me Flix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flix. -- And how do you live? What  kind of a person are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a prodigal son, the black sheep  of a white flock -- I shall die on  the gallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, I haven't a bit of character.  None at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a little boy I was taught  to ride and be a gentleman -- at  school, it was a monastery, I learned  to pray and lie -- and ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, in the war, to kill and  hide. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you do -- now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a gambler -- I'm running at large  like a happy pig, devouring anything  of life that pleases me, I really  belong in jail

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! What a picture -- and what else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seriously) I'm also a criminal and a hotel thief. (he turns away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a silly joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns -- takes both  her hands) Please look at me. You must believe  me -- you must believe that I love  you -- that I have never known what  love is -- until last night. (he releases her hands  and turns away again.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flix!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron takes the pearls out of his pocket and lays the before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little cry of  pain) Oh -- (in the silence  Grusinskaya puts her  head in her hands  and thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron makes a gesture as if to stroke her hair and th holds back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Did you come here just -- just for  that? Oh -- it's horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. She is suddenly cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may keep the pearls -- I don't  want them any more -- I'll make you  a present of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passionately) I don't want them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (broken) I'll not denounce you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday I was a thief -- but now, --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now, you must go... I give you  the pearls. But now you must go ---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted money desperately -- Can  you understand? -- That's why I wanted  the pearls. I was threatened -- I  was desperately in need of a certain  big sum of money. I've been following  you -- I've admired you. But I have  forced myself not to think about you --  Last night, at last, I managed to  came into your room and -- and now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) And now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't go through with it. (his head goes down  into her lap -- he  sighs:) Remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hand touches her hair -- tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- yes -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a sudden knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly -- here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a quick gesture Grusinskaya beckons the Baron to the bathroom. He disappears into the bathroom. She opens the  door, after finding the key and radiantly addresses Suzet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted to see her  in a good mood) Good morning, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the coffee down on the table. Charming piece of business as Suzette, in putting the cof down on the table must necessarily push back the heavily  crested cigarette case of the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam has slept well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enthusiastically) Oh, yes, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam will dress now, it is late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes, Suzette, come back in  five minutes. I'll ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, madam Suzette knows all about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is a French woman. She is pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam is beautiful this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Grusinskaya hurries Suzette to the door she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette goes out. Quickly Grusinskaya crosses and flings  open the bathroom door. The Baron comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks the telephone goes. She gives the telephone dirty look. Telephone rings again. She pulls him across t the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There -- it begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a hand in his she lifts the telephone receiver and  speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello -- hello -- Meierheim? Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this scene the Baron is touching her shoulder. A  charming light moment. She continues to speak into teleph His touch probably tickles her, she laughs -- quickly cov the receiver so that Meierheim will not hear her laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Baron) No --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this scene she is listening to Meierheim. She frow suddenly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?... Cancel Vienna?... Are you  mad? We always have great success in  Vienna... Certainly not. Come here  and see me... yes... good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to the Baron and their arms go around each othe The telephone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) There -- the day begins... I must go  to rehearsal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lets the telephone ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do believe that I really love  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- If I didn't believe that, I'd  die after last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be good to you -- madly  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette will be back here in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go -- good-bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I see you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone bell rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette will be back here any minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you leaving Berlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very early in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Vienna?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't -- can't you -- Couldn't you  come too -- I think it would be better --  for us -- for us both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- yes but -- later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no money now -- I must get  some first -- I must get some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you what you need -- I  have money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no -- that would spoil everything.  I'll -- I will manage somehow --  I'll manage myself. I will go with  you. When does the train leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six twenty-seven in the morning...  But the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind -- I'll get it. I have a  whole day. I'll be on that train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall dance and you'll be with me  and then -- listen -- After that you  will come with me to Lake Como, I  have a villa there. The sun will be  shining. I will take a vacation --  six weeks -- eight weeks. We'll be  happy and lazy. And then you will go  with me to South America -- oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telephone starts ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must go now. Be careful on your  way to your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go. -- I love you. (he kisses her) I'll be on that train. I'll get the  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds him back. The telephone is ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do anything foolish -- I'm  alarmed about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll be on the train. (he kisses her) He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone with the telephone bell ringing, Grusinskaya breath deeply, stretches herself. She goes to the glass and look at herself -- smiling. Happily she takes the pearls, kiss them, drops them into the casket -- picks up the telephon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking into  telephone) Yes, Pimenov... Yes... where are  you, in your room? Come, I will see  you now... hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rises from the telephone flutteringly, she is humming tune. She crosses to the mirror, pulls back her hair happ she is indeed younger. Suzette is putting out a dark dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that dark dress -- something  light -- bright -- it's a sunny  morning, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette happily glances at her. There is a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. (sings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pimenov enters, before he can speak --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Pimenov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little puzzled at  change in her) Good morning, Gru -- your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he can start speaking of last night she quickly sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pimenov, I have an idea -- a new  ballet -- it must have mad music --  I'll explain it to you later. But  now, hurry to the theatre -- I want  full rehearsal -- properties -- full  ballet and some musicians. Hurry --  Quickly. I will be there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this scene Grusinskaya has not looked at him, she busy in the glass. Nice photography on hair and face. Side scene between Suzette and Pimenov, as Suzette shows the cigarette case on the table. As he goes through the door Grusinskaya crosses and almos sweeps Suzette to the door with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gru -- you are positively radiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Pimenov. (quickly to Suzette) One minute, Suzette, I will call  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave. Grusinskaya shuts the door. She sweeps happily to the  telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very very softly -  her voice is like  music to operator) Hello -- will you -- will you get me  Baron von Gaigern, please... yes...  Baron von Gaigern -- yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While she waits, she moves with a sense of dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again into telephone) Will you get me Baron von Gaigern,  please... (she speaks quietly) Cherie... yes... it is you...  nothing... good morning, good morning,  cherie... nothing... no... just to  tell you I'm happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring music up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music effect over sign "Grand Hotel." Precisely the same  angle as before. The sign lights.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY
dialogues.text: The music comes up on the DISSOLVE into the original key  shot of the lobby. Senf is busy. The Baron's chauffeur is standing impatiently by his desk Business ad lib of Senf. He turns to the chauffeur who is barring the way of an important looking alien.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step back please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chauffeur makes no effort to move. Against the normal bus happy traffic of the evening he is a sinister figure. He  does not move but glares at Senf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've told you three times -- Baron  von Gaigern is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he leave any message for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he did not -- there is no message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This whole scene is played in a very low key, almost in a whisper, it is interrupted by the entrance of the Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Senf) Any letters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this short scene the chauffeur saunters off. Kringelein comes to the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Doctor, such a day -- such a  day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move away from the scene. Kringelein's voice diminishes as the CAMERA MOVES followi the chauffeur. The chauffeur saunters unthoughtfully past the florist sh and out of the door. As we pass the florist shop we see t back of the Baron in the shot. CAMERA PANS chauffeur out to door. He has not seen the Ba in the florist shop. THE CAMERA PANS back to florist shop waits for the Baron who emerges carrying his usual box of orchids. CAMERA FOLLOWS BARON back to Senf's desk. Key sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Senf) Madam Grusinskaya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the flowers  and handing them to  clerk) For Madam Grusinskaya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to page boy) Madam Grusinskaya -- at once --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Baron) Your chauffeur's been waiting, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Quickly -- shortly) All right. (he glances around  apprehensively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein is speaking to the doctor. The Baron approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron, we must have gone a hundred  miles an hour, at least...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to doctor) We've been together all day... and  in an aeroplane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life is changing you, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thanks to the Baron. The best  shops, the very best. Look, Doctor,  silk -- feels so nice on the skin...  a London hat, see -- made in England,  that's silk, too -- fifty marks...  Look, the price is on it. That was  half my salary before. The Baron is  a very fine gentleman -- no one in  my life has been so nice to me as  the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron smiles. He slaps his gauntlets on his dusty coa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to change and we'll meet  for a drink in the Yellow Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Yellow Room, where the music's  playing and the ladies are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Where the music's playing and the  ladies are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pain, Mr. Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pain? Oh, no, Doctor. I think if I  had pain I'd be too happy to notice  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOTE: Find cut here. While Kringelein is talking, they move away from the CAME

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF BARON'S ROOM
dialogues.text: The Baron enters, throws his gloves down on the bed, turn up the light, picks up a piece of paper that's been pushe under the door, glances at it.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAPER
dialogues.text: In scrawl: "I HAVE BEEN WAITING ALL DAY. WILL BE OUTSIDE

dialogues.speaker: BARON
dialogues.text: We again see the apprehension on the Baron's face. He cro closes the window. As he does so we hear the noise from t conference room. Bring up noise from the conference room.

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: We must have the feeling that these men have been arguing all day. Cognac bottles, cigar ends, selzer water, remain of some sandwiches. In other words it is a business  battlefield. Preysing is drawn and tired. Zinnowitz is on his feet. Flaemmchen is fast asleep in her chair, making pretty picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and let me say again for the tenth  time... (he is hoarse and  tired) ...you people were quite ready for  the merger. You declared yourselves...  fully agreed on all the terms -- Why  should the signing of these articles  be suddenly held up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've admitted that at one time we  had reason for desiring ther merger --  What reason have we now? The Preysing  Company has fallon upon evil days,  very evil days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evil days -- I've shown you here -- (he bangs the paper) -- my company exports to the Balkans  alone, sixty-five thousand marks  worth of mop rags a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mop rags -- mop rags -- we're  interested in something quite  different!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gerstenkorn --  with a sigh) Shall I tell them again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at his watch) Why waste time -- it's getting late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see -- what we are interested in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Ah, come on -- we're going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Due to the long tedious session the men's collars are wil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Mr. Preysing has too scrupulous a  regard for certainties...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've talked enough today, you're  hoarse now.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING
dialogues.text: His hand goes to his pocket. Slowly he takes out the tele and glances at it. The following scene is played over thi closeup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Preysing. (he gets his hat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) You've decided against the merger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, it's all over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Zinnowitz) Well -- well -- You could call my  office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a general movement to go.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF TELEGRAM
dialogues.text: Trembling in Preysing's hand. "DEAL WITH MANCHESTER DEFIN

dialogues.speaker: ROOM
dialogues.text: Gerstenkorn crosses to Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Preysing, I hope you pull  through. This is a very bad time to  be in such a crisis. We've...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Why talk -- it's over -- it's over --  it's finished. You've broken off  negotiations. You did it. You're  calling them off. You had nothing on  your mind all day, but Manchester, --  Manchester -- Manchester. (he develops almost a  passion) You don't suppose for one moment  that I'm such a fool as not to have  something that I could say definitely  about Manchester. (he is generating  almost a passion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no -- no -- the session is over.  Let's go, it's off. Thank you,  gentlemen. (he starts packing up  his papers.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you actually have news from  Manchester then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I am now free to  announce... (he is perspiring,  his hands are  trembling) ...that the deal between my firm and  the Manchester Cotton Company has  been successfully negotiated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing, you're joking with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a deep one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case give us the articles.  We'll sign at once. We know all the  details...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, slowly folds  up the telegram and  puts it back in his  pocket) I thought we'd suspended negotiations,  gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under these circumstances it's quite  a different matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under these circumstances we might  refuse to sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time, Waitz and Zinnowitz have the articles out u the table. Preysing is perspiring. Gerstenkorn puts his arms around Preysing's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- business is business --  Come on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing stands, looking ahead of him. Gerstenkorn picks up the papers glances at them, looks at Waitz. Flaemmchen is awakening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my signature -- here Preysing,  sign here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a session this has been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Preysing is signing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's twenty-five to six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should celebrate this with a bottle  of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with his hat and  coat) See you soon, Preysing. Next week  we'll meet and discuss further  details.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hasty hand-shaking, business of exits. Waitz, Gerstenkorn and Schweimann out. Preysing has not moved. Zinnowitz takes the agreement and waves it in the air to the signature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let me talk till I'm hoarse and  you had Manchester sewed-up all the  time. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing does not answer. Zinnowitz amiably shrugs his shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- the deal has been put through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing commences to laugh suddenly with increasing viol

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it has been put through -- it  has been put through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this scene, Flaemmchen has risen, piled up her pap glanced at her watch. During this action Flaemmchen motio to Zinnowitz that she is going down to dance, etc., Preys is unaware of this action. Flaemmchen leaves the room try not to attract attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Preysing) What's the matter with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterically) Bluff -- Bluff -- all bluff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's bluff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing the telegram  on the table) That.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading at out loud) 'Deal with Manchester definitely  off! "Preysing, oh -- I'd never have  thought it of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one would have thought it of me.  I've been getting rusty in  Fredersdorf. Well, if bluff is what  the world wants I guess I can put up  as big a bluff as anyone. From now  on... (he turns away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must go to Manchester at once  yourself and really see it through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- I must go to England -- I was  desperate -- Now I don't care --  This sort of thing goes to a man's  head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you need is some relaxation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- that's what I want -- I'd  like to tear loose -- I'd like a  drink. I'd like to go down to that  dancing place. I'd like to start  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can understand that -- after your --  uh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it -- say it -- my lie -- it's  the first time in thirty years that  I've ever... Where's that  stenographer? Miss Flaemm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see her, I want to do some  dictating -- report of the conference  for my father-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had an engagement in the Yellow  Room at five o'clock -- she was in a  hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zinnowitz, would you say she was  pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty as a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go down and find her -- I need  a drink -- Come along Zinnowitz. (he is picking up  papers) I don't know anything about women --  been married for twenty-six years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluff does it, Preysing, bluff does  it. Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing is very excited, they start to leave -- at that  moment the telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aeh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Hello... Father-in-law?... Is that  you?... The agreement is signed -- I  did it... yes, father-in-law... but  now I must go to Manchester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he picks the telephone up his hands are shaking --

dialogues.speaker: COCKTAIL SHAKER
dialogues.text: -- which shakes more. Music crashes up --

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE INTO BAR
dialogues.text: Kringelein and the Doctor are just entering. Kringelein i changed. His hair has been cut short and his moustache is gone, he looks almost saucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to barman) Barman -- whiskey -- (to Kringelein) For you, Mr. Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me? -- Oh, please, something  sweet and cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Louisiana flip, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Louisiana flip, that sounds very  nice -- sweet, eh? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the following speech Kringelein keeps reaching for the moustache that is not there. He is thoroughly happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do in the Grand Hotel?  Eat -- sleep -- loaf around -- do  business -- flirt a little -- dance  a little. A hundred doors to one  hall and nobody knows anything about  the person next to him. When you  leave another takes your room and  lies in your bed -- the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment Flaemmchen enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Mr. Kringelein --  Where's the Baron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for him here. The Baron  and I have been together all day. A  hundred miles an hour -- in a motor  car -- and in an aeroplane -- It was  marvelous --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kringelein -- How you have  changed, you look so nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, Miss Flaemm. Oh,  please, Miss Flaemm -- Permit me,  Miss Flaemm, won't you have something  sweet -- a Louisiana flip. (to barman) A Louisiana flip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to barman) No - absinthe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) Yes -- that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein is beating time to the music -- a little carri away. Flaemmchen laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- it's stimulating -- a man  might --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mischievously) A man might what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- I'd like to do  anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very quietly) Oh -- you would!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron enters quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Flaemmchen) Hello -- sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- here you are, Baron. A drink --  A Louisiana flip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Kringelein. How do you  feel now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little strange, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd given you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Flaemmchen) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drink, Baron -- A Louisiana flip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks -- keeping my head clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance then? (they exit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Doctor) She's beautiful -- isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kringelein) Oh -- there are plenty of women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been doing all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chasing around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chasing what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dance a few steps, in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were very different yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday -- yes -- that was  yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dance into the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Kringelein, are you getting  what you're looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A masculine paradise -- drink, the  ladies, dancing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a very good opportunity, a  young lady asked me to dance -- I  ought to be able to dance, it seems  to be very important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must learn as quickly as your  time allows -- Believe me Mr.  Kringelein, a man who isn't with a  woman is a dead man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you anyone -- Haven't you  anybody -- you -- I mean -- Are you  all alone in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'm always alone -- I have been  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sent as a military surgeon to  South Africa. Stinking climate. Taken  prisoner. Home on parole not to fight.  I was a surgeon in the Great War  till the end. Grenade in the face.  Carried diphtheria bacilli in the  wound until 1920. Isolated two years. (pause) I've been everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music has stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you do me a big favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do anything for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to make a man happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes -- I'd love to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then dance the next number with  Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel sorry for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a bit like you were  yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fell in love last night -- the  real thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- there's no real thing -- it  doesn't exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought that, too -- but I found  that it does. Come along, dance with  Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move off. As they approach the bar, happily Preysing pushes into scene, touches Flaemmchen's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Flaemm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must speak with you, Miss Flaemm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the Baron) Presently, Mr. Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, the lady has urgent  business here with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) Insolent -- Berlin manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment Kringelein has descended from the stool an crosses to Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you a very good evening, Mr.  Preysing. You are staying here, too,  Mr. Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- you must know me -- Kringelein  at the plant. Assistant bookkeeper,  building C, room twenty-three --  third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Come and dance with me, Mr.  Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must speak to you, Miss Flaemm --  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) Tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you gentlemen know each other,  Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Preysing --  Baron von Gaigern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They bow stiffly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Kringelein will be a good friend  and not accept your invitation to  dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could not think of not accepting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say that you are employed by us  in Fredersdorf, and here you are in  Berlin, indulging in diversions which  ill befit your position and which  are very much beyond your means --  Quite extraordinary, Mr. Kringelein,  I think we will look into your books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein stands watching Preysing, his eyes narrowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, children, no fighting -- save  that for the office. Let's have our  dance. (her arms go around  Kringelein. They  dance off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll remember you, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let the poor devil alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not ask your advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men eye each other; for a moment there might be a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it would be much better if  you went away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall see who remains here the  longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging his  shoulders) As you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing leans against the bar, orders a cognac. The Baro turns his back to him, watching the dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must look at my face and not at  the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never danced before -- in public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dance splendidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happy, Miss Flaemm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time in my life, I'm  happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein shows signs of exhaustion. Flaemmchen watches him quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's stop -- I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is obvious that she has stopped because of Kringelein' distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Flaemm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move back to the bar. Preysing catches Flaemmchen's  arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now, Miss Flaemm, we can talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some champagne, Miss Flaemm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may go, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does the world belong to you, Mr.  Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this insolence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you have free license  to be insulting? Believe me you have  not. You think you're superior, but  you're quite an ordinary man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away -- go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like to see me enjoying  myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? -- An embezzler most  likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An embezzler -- you're going to take  that back, right here in the presence  of this young lady -- who do you  think you're talking to? You think  I'm dirt, if I'm dirt, you're a lot  dirtier, Mr. Industrial Magnate  Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're discharged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you -- shut your mouth -- get  out -- you're discharged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein's hat has fallen from the stool upon the floor Flaemmchen picks it up, brushes it. Kringelein starts to laugh. The Baron steps into the scene. The Doctor slowly comes from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't discharge me -- I'm my own  master now -- at last. I'm ill, I'm  going to die -- do you understand?  I'm going to die very soon. Nothing  can happen to me now. Nobody can do  anything any more to me. By the time  you can have discharged me I shall  have been dead already. (his laugh becomes a  convulsive sob)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron steps between the two looking straight into  Preysing's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Mr. Kringelein. (he pulls him out of  the scene towards  the bar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his fists clenched,  between his teeth) The man's insane -- he acts as if he  is glad he is going to die... (hesitates -- to  Flaemmchen) I shall see you in the lobby in half  an hour.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY OVER SENF'S HEAD
dialogues.text: General activity. The house detective, later identified, is talking to the  chauffeur. He leaves the chauffeur and crosses to Senf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better let him stay -- I've sent for  the Baron... How's your wife coming  along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at the hospital all night  walking up and down the corridor.  They wouldn't let me in to see her.  She has the pains, but the child  doesn't come and I have to stay here  chained to this desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment Preysing enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you send that page?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young lady's there, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing glances off to see Flaemmchen standing looking  around. Preysing crosses to Flaemmchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, Mr. Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit here. (calls to a boy) Cognac -- for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment the Baron and Kringelein pass. Preysing glances up at Kringelein as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to keep an eye on that  Kringelein fellow. I'll find out  where he gets the money to hang around  the Grand Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- you want me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks straight at  her) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go to England -- at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, I'd like to take a secretary  with me for my correspondence and -- humm -- humm -- for company on the  trip -- I'm nervous -- I need somebody --  I don't know if you quite understand  me. You said you have travelled with  gentlemen -- and I mean --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand perfectly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think your salary would  be -- for such a trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- I must figure it up. (she smokes and thinks) First, I'll need -- clothes -- shoes --  it's cold in England in March, I'll  need a suit... You'd want me to look  nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course -- of course. (he is fidgeting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thousand marks -- (she waits anxiously  thinking it might be  too much)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's agreed -- I will get a room  here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is looking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get a room here in the Grand  Hotel for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She still looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you pay some attention to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off) Insolent young cub!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Baron von Gaigern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he's a gentleman!

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: Who is leaning against a chair by a pillar with Kringelei THE CAMERA APPROACHES THEM. They are not speaking. The Baron is looking off at:

dialogues.speaker: CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Sauntering between the door and Senf's desk.

dialogues.speaker: THE BARON
dialogues.text: He slumps on the arm of the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching him) The Baron is tired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Kringelein, not tired, -- just -- (he shrugs his  shoulders) Well -- well --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps this evening, Baron, we could  go to the Casino -- the place we  passed with the marvelous bright  lights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to Kringelein, but I can't --  I am broke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Broke -- A Baron? But, Baron --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron looks off, sees the chauffeur --

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Arguing with Senf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Kringelein. (he strides off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the CAMERA on Kringelein as he watches the Baron. He takes out his pocket-book and looks at his money comme to count it. The thought is in his mind of offering the B money. Charming scene.

dialogues.speaker: BARON AND CHAUFFEUR
dialogues.text: Moving into position. They are talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I've quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to get those pearls  and neither are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have an idea working in my head... (he glances at  Kringelein)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might find a bullet through that  head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you did that, you'd get nothing  except the police after you. If you  wait -- I'll give you your six  thousand back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment a voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car -- Madam  Grusinskaya's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is passed along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls through his  little telephone) Madam Grusinskaya's car --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outside) Madam Grusinskaya's car --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly to chauffeur) Later. (Chauffeur exits with  bad grace.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron looks off...

dialogues.speaker: FROM HIS ANGLE
dialogues.text: Like a pageant Grusinskaya sweeps forward -- pretty shot. Music comes up. Grusinskaya is followed by Suzette, Pimenov and Meierheim People turn to look at her. She sweeps forward. As she gets to the door she faces the Baron. She steps qu aside to him. Pimenov and Meierheim pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to them) Go on please -- go on, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She and the Baron are alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Bless you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you coming to the theatre? Oh --  I shall dance tonight -- How I shall  dance -- I want to feel that you are  in the theatre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I can't explain now. Oh, look --  the pearls. You wear them now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've brought me such good luck --  you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand, kisses it quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- I will be on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this scene Kringelein has been hovering nearby. As Grusinskaya turns away and exits, Kringelein approaches t Baron, who is standing perfectly still, looking off, -- h mind miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was the Baron joking, or is it really  true that the Baron is -- in financial  straits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) Absolutely true, Kringelein and I  have to raise some money immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the Baron -- if you would permit  me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron looks at him suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would be awfully glad to oblige,  you've been so decent to me. Three  hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could get into a game I might  win some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gambling! I'd like that. I have over  six thousand eight hundred marks  with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we could scare up some men to  play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could come to my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with enthusiasm) Good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment Flaemmchen passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen hesitates as though she wanted to say somethin that is on her mind. A curious little scene. She doesn't speak, she just turns suddenly through the do The Baron glances after her a little puzzled, turns back Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready, Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move off and are last in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No scenes 88-93 inclusive Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Possibly ten men are gathered about a green table. They a playing cards. There are champagne bottles, glasses, etc. on the table -- a great deal of smoke. Good atmosphere. T game is [...] fer. There is a dead silence except for the monotonous words of the players. White faced, the Baron has the bank. Otternschlag is seen to close the door quietly and approa the table. Kringelein's back is to us. They are smart people, not professional gamblers. There is a tension in the room. The men are gathered arou tightly. We do not see the cards. The following voices are heard:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I play -- I play -- Here -- Up --  Playing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several men glance at Kringelein and the size of his stak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that too much, Baron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances down at his  own money) No -- not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is tension in the room. The Baron deals two cards.  Kringelein takes cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Don't show them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein turns it down. He is like a little boy learnin new game. The Baron deals himself a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Baron) What do I do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron is serious. There is enough money on the table take him to Vienna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (next to Kringelein) Turn 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes -- that's right -- look! I  win, don't I -- (he turns the card up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kringelein) Will you take the bank, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- I'll take everything gentlemen --  please, let us drink -- champagne --- champagne is expensive and good. I'm  winning more than I used to earn in  a year -- double what I used to earn. (he is counting his  money)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hand him the cards. Kringelein kisses the Baron -- he looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the Baron -- where are you,  Baron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the side table the Baron is standing -- he is drinking his face is white -- he has lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising quickly) Excuse me, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting down in  Kringelein's place) I'll take the bank -- All right,  gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein has come to the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've lost everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Baron. Permit me again... (he puts bills in  Baron's hand.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron pours out a glass of champagne -- he has been drink plenty -- he hands glass to Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink to me, Kringelein -- it's my  last chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) I do drink, Baron -- I drink to you,  Baron and to win. (he drinks) It's good, -- come along, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both move back to the table where the Doctor holds t bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take five hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of that at once, Baron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron picks cards, shows them to Kringelein who doesn understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight. (he is triumphant.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rings in background) Nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron throws the cards into the middle of the table a turns to Kringelein:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. The luck's with you. (he walks away.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along, Mr. Kringelein. Sit here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having luck for the first time  in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bank, Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein seats himself, puts his glass of champagne dow on the table. Doctor leaves table, crosses to Baron who is pouring anot drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out, Baron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) For a while -- I'll recover -- in  ten or twenty years. (he points) Look at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has pointed and turned off because we hear Kringelein' voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've won again, Baron -- I've won  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron moves out of scene followed by Doctor. As Baron  approaches table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron, I drink and win -- I drink  and win -- I win and drink! (he is pulling money  towards him, counting  it, eagerly,  frantically, not the  movement of a miser,  not a greedy movement,  but the movement of  an excited child  liberated. Money has  become so much mad  paper to him.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the foregoing scene, one of the men at the table h answered the ringing of the telephone bell, he comes back now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are complaints in the hotel  about the noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it? Getting late? Let's  break it up! (to Kringelein) You've been very lucky... Where's my  coat? Let's go. He's drunk anyway!...  Goodnight, Baron. Let's wind up the  game, I'm broke and tired; you can't  play against him. I put my hat down  here, somewhere. I think I'll have a  drink before I go. By the way, I've  got to see you tomorrow morning.  How've you been, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business ad lib. General business of slow normal exit. Kringelein looks up from counting his money. He has been  like a little boy with a Christmas stocking. He looks up  suddenly, sees men are leaving --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't go, gentlemen! -- Stay a  while. (he stands to his  feet) Be my guests!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time the men are pausing by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I oughtn't to presume, but I -- (he is a little drunk) I'm so grateful to you -- it's been  so marvelous. The first time in my  life I have gambled -- I've danced!  Oh, you can laugh, gentlemen, but  it's the first time in my life I've  ever tasted life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping him on back) Splendid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a general feeling in the room that although this man is drunk he is terribly sincere, and that there is no wish to embarrass themselves or him. In fact, there is a  nervous impatient movement among the men. But Kringelein reached an emotional pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life, gentlemen, is wonderful, but  very dangerous. You must have courage  for it, then it's wonderful. You  gentlemen don't know that because  you are all healthy and happy, but I --  believe me -- a man must know death  and not until then does a man know  anything about life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings) Rejoice in life while yet the small  lamp burns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General noise among men, some are ribald, others are seri Two men come and shake hands with Kringelein, bidding him goodnight. The Baron puts his hand restrainingly on Kringelein's  shoulder. Kringelein almost staggers towards the sideboard. The men are nearing the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts singing) It's a short life and a gay one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seizing a glass of  champagne) Every glass high to life -- the  splendid, dangerous, mighty, brief -- brief life -- and the courage to  live it. (turns to Baron) Baron, you know -- I've only lived  since last night -- but that little  while seems longer than all the time  before -- all the -- (he collapses suddenly  onto the floor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business ad lib. The doctor is there quickly. The Baron next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General normal business ad lib between the men. Perhaps t of them help him up, including the Baron. They carry  Kringelein to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of players mingling) Drunk? No, he's ill. Looks ill. (well paused over:) He's a doctor -- The doctor's here --  He's just drunk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this man is ill -- very  ill -- if you will leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Doctor. Goodnight!  Goodnight, Baron! Bad luck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not used to champagne -- why  does he drink it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little comedy on exit. Ad lib. INTERCUT FOR RELIEF -- Kringelein's face -- white, drawn, tragic. One man, perhaps, remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help, doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the Baron will stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man leaves. During this scene the Baron has been carefull making Kringelein comfortable on the bed, bolstering pill behind his head. Kringelein's eyes are shut tightly, his  hands are limp. By the business of the Baron, although we do not of cours know it, this is the time that he takes the wallet from  Kringelein and puts it in his own pocket. We might perhaps remember a sudden turn away in which we his back and his right hand raised as though reaching in inside pocket -- He stands looking down at Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drops Kringelein's  hand) It will be over in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein's eyes flutter. His voice sounds hoarsely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over -- over so soon -- it has just  begun. (he closes his eyes  suddenly) Oh, the pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try and sleep, Kringelein, don't be  afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutteringly) I'd like to live a little longer but --  I'm not afraid to die -- I'm not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching his shoulder  gently) You'll be all right, Kringelein. (he moves from the  bed -- takes out a  cigarette, moves to  the table. He seizes  his drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of scene) My pocketbook... my money in it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say -- what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We watch Baron's face, he looks back over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what -- Oh, isn't it there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- But no I -- Baron, I've lost  my pocketbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron turns in this scene. He walks forward toward them. The Doctor's hands are on Kringelein's coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no pocketbook here... On  the floor probably. (He glances down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting up suddenly) More than fourteen thousand marks...  were in that pocketbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Baron) Fourteen thousand marks... One can  travel -- one's happiness might depend  on fourteen thousand marks -- don't  you think so, Baron?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a shrug) Quite possibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, Kringelein, who has been staring up at th ceiling, his hands clenching and reclenching, starts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I've got to find it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay where you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I must find it -- (he starts talking) Fourteen thousand two hundred marks. (he pulls himself to  the side of the bed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor goes to restrain him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right, Doctor. There's no  pain now -- only you don't know what  that money means to a man like me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is suddenly on his hands and knees, crawling along the floor, looking for it, like a little boy; his drunkenness his condition, makes the situation tragic. He actually ge under the card table. The Doctor looks at the Baron. The Baron only watches Kringelein. He follows him, fascin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking at intervals  as he crawls looking  for money) You don't know, because you've never  lived like a dog -- in a hole -- and  saved and scrimped. My life hangs  upon that money, Baron. Nobody gives  you anything. You have to buy  everything and pay cash for it. I  wanted to pay for my last days with  that money. Every hour costs money.  I've nothing -- nothing but that  pocketbook. (he crawls along the  floor on his hands  and knees talking to  the carpet as he  looks) I must have it back. (he pauses breathless --  like an animal along  the wall -- looking  up at the men)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foregoing speech is intercut with the following actio in which Kringelein's voice is heard throughout -- thus i is not a long speech: The Baron watches. He throws his cigarette away -- he bit his lip -- sweat breaks out upon his forehead; again he i thief. When he wanted pearls the love of a woman stopped  him. Now he wants this money and pity, a slow growing pit for this tragic, dying thing is stopping him -- and all t time the Doctor watches. The one, whole eye pierces into the Baron's melting  conscience. Twice during the speech at a spot, through and during  rehearsal, to be selected, the Doctor's voice, droning bu piercing, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must find his money, Baron. (next time) Mr. Kringelein should find his  pocketbook, Baron, shouldn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are two interjections. And now, Kringelein lies upon the floor, a troubled littl sack of pain, his head down. The Baron turns away. He bends down as though he were loo for the pocketbook. We see him take it from his pocket an turn. There is a very light, almost triumphant ring in hi voice as he says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- here it is. Here's your  pocketbook, Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his head coming up) Oh -- yes -- that's it -- you found  it -- you found it for me, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Goodnight, Kringelein. (he moves towards the  door.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- no please -- oh, don't go --  don't go -- don't leave me alone,  Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've nothing to fear, Kringelein

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, get up -- come let me help  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOTE: If he is a strong actor he can pick Kringelein up - If not, he and Doctor lift Kringelein to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all right now -- it's very  late -- goodnight, Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, stay here, Baron -- stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron bites his lip. It is the first and only time in the play that we see a tear near -- the strong man almost bre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight. (his hand presses on  Kringelein's shoulder --  he exits)

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Baron shuts door and pauses. In front of him is the door the woman he loves. Down beyond is his own empty room. In his pockets nothing. In his CLOSEUP he makes the audience feel his problem with him. This man who has lived and whistled and love through the  play becomes a tragic, lonely, harrassed figure. The Baro has broken. His fists dig into his eyes -- he brushes his hair back. Over this comes with almost an impertinence, a tiny whist He looks up and away down the corridor. The figure of  Flaemmchen stands there, a small black bag in her hand. T Baron pulls himself together and smiles characteristicall He walks down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen, what are you doing here  in the middle of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for my room -- one sixty- six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For tonight. (she points to door --  she looks at him a  long time)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- such is life, Flaemmchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Baron, thanks so much for  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both go into their respective rooms. Here are our two gay young characters. The gay, fresh  Flaemmchen and the debonair Baron, crucified for lack of  funds. Both trying to smile, both trying to be light abou themselves. Yet, each about to involve themselves tragica for the want of a little money.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen enters her room cautiously. Except for one lam burning the room is in darkness and empty. From the adjoi door to Preysing's room a thin stream of light. She puts  down her bag quickly, tiptoes through the bathroom to his door. She peeps through.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF PREYSING'S ROOM
dialogues.text: from her angle. Preysing stretched on bed flat, his stomach a mountain an on it the magazine that he has been reading with Flaemmch picture. He is looking at the ceiling. She knows he is aw because a thin stream of smoke comes from his cigar in hi hand.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF FLAEMMCHEN
dialogues.text: An idea occurs to her. She could possibly sneak into bed he would go to sleep and there would be nothing that nigh CAMERA FOLLOWS HER as she tiptoes to her room. She closes the door noiselessly and listens. She throws off her hat takes off her coat. Opens her bag and takes out night dre lingerie, etc. The lid of her bag falls suddenly. She sta at the noise. "Has it awakened him." She looks off.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT AT BATHROOM DOOR
