dialogues.text: The thin stream of light is filled suddenly, the door of adjoining room opens and back-lighted from the other room the huge form of Preysing appears. In this odd lighting h is a little more than Preysing. He comes forward. He spea hoarsely, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen! (he seizes her to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to his arms passively. He rubs his face in her h She is passive -- cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathlessly) You are late. I've been waiting for  you -- waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to arrange about the trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her again, trying to kiss her. She deliberately  avoids his kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Come here. (he sits heavily on  the bed, sitting on  her night dress.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, hold up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing rises while she pulls her night dress from under him. He draws her to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me -- do you know -- would you --  would you like to call me by my first  name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away, glad  of an excuse for  conversation) Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't do that, you're a stranger  to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a funny little creature,  Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not funny at all. One can't get  intimate just off hand. I could go  to England with you and everything  like that -- supposing I met you  next year and I said: 'How do you  do, Mr. Preysing! And you said: (she imitates him) 'That was the young lady who was my  secretary in Manchester'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing laughs. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all quite proper. (she is happy again.  She would rather  talk than be squeezed) But supposing I met you when you  were with your wife and I called  out: "Hello you big baby -- remember  Manchester?' And you with your wife,  how would you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Flaemmchen -- we'll leave my  wife out of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen yawns straight in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'll get undressed -- get  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves towards the windows which are open. She pushes h fat body out, almost playfully, through the doors and ont the balcony. Preysing stands out on the balcony. He looks down in the  street below, then off. He starts suddenly because he see shadow over the railing of his own balcony. He is puzzled Shadow crosses again. "Who can be in his room?" He moves  forward and peeps through the window. One side of the Fre window is closed. From his angle we see the Baron furtive searching the room. He is now wearing an overcoat, the co is turned up. Business ad lib. He finds Preysing's wallet He stuffs this in his overcoat pocket. Preysing's face  watching him. As Baron turns to exit, Preysing surges for pulling the window after him. The two men face each other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have made a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made a mistake -- remarkable. We  shall soon see if you made a mistake. (the Baron starts to  leave.) (bellowing) Stay here... Give me that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron hands him the pocketbook without a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's how we stand, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here, sir -- I'm completely at  your mercy -- I'm desperate -- it's  a matter of life or death -- I had  to get some money -- tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed you must, Baron -- you must.  Humm -- humm, but you must go to  jail, Baron, you're a thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to call the police. I'm  going to watch you play the great  Baron with the police. Aristocrat!  Aristocrat! (he picks up the  telephone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron makes for the door on the other side of the roo pulls at the knob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is locked, Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron makes one dive across the room. Preysing grasps his coat and tears it. With one hand holding the telephon (the receiver dropping on its cord towards the ground) an one hand holding the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) Hello! Hello! --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that. (he tries to snatch  the telephone from  Preysing.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing wrenches the telephone suddenly away from the Ba The action excites him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike me, would you? Attack me would  you? Attack me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a terrific lunge, Preysing brings the telephone down upon the Baron's head. The Baron sways, stunned. (as in b In his mad rage, Preysing, hits again with the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll strike you -- I'll strike you --  I'll strike you -- Strike me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this time the Baron is a heap on the floor. We see Pre come out of his blind trance. He even repeats again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I strike you -- (with telephone  foolishly in his  hand, he looks down  at what he has done.)

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS TELEPHONE ROOM
dialogues.text: Sharp sound of buzzing. Dozing night girl plugs in, lazily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- yes -- Operator -- Operator -- (she listens -- says  to herself) They are having a nice little game  up there with the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With nonchalance she flicks plug out again, as she does s

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING'S ROOM
dialogues.text: New angle. Preysing is on his feet. He has replaced the  receiver on the telephone, he is putting it back slowly. is terrified. Door opens behind him. Flaemmchen, with a dressing gown on, light, filmy thing,  crosses and looks down at the Baron, without a word. Prey seizes her. Her hand goes to her head, her eyes roll; for a moment we think she is going to faint right on top of the Baron. Sh is trying to collect her senses, it cannot be true. We ca hear nothing but the heavy breathing of Preysing and the  traffic below. Suddenly a motor horn in the street below sounds strident it is the first time we have been conscious of it. With a swift movement, Flaemmchen dashes towards the door It is locked. She rushes back as if to cut through her ow room. He reaches for her and rips her dressing gown from  her, leaving her almost naked. He lunges after her. She t through her own room.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Flaemmchen enters from her room. She looks this way and t After all, it is Flaemmchen and not Lillian Gish, running across the ice in "Way Down East," -- it is Flaemmchen, a Berlin girl. She pauses to try and clear her brain. "What the hell is this -- what is it." The impulse naturally is scream in alarm. She doesn't -- Flaemmchen's don't. She l around. At the end of the passage is Kringelein's room. S will go there. We watch her run down the passage uncertai Without knocking she pushes open Kringelein's door.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: It is in darkness. The only light comes through the windo The form of Kringelein lies prone upon the bed, the Docto had just thrown a coat over him. He is still in his trous and shirt. Like a ghost, Flaemmchen, the shreds of her filmy clothes hanging to her, crosses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hoarse whisper) Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Kringelein --  where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sweeps to bed. She shakes him. Kringelein starts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick -- Mr. Kringelein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- what -- what -- (he is looking up at  what seems to be a  ghost.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls on the light by the bed, it flames up on their  faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- oh, Miss Flaemmchen. It's you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick -- something awful -- awful  has happened. Go -- go at once, --  Mr. Preysing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It occurs to him that this girl with her torn clothes mus have been roughly treated by Preysing. He suddenly assume strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't wait -- go -- it's awful --  it's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slides down to the floor, by the side of the bed. Kringelein climbs out of bed, tries to help her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wait now -- go -- Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein assumes suddenly a strength. He is a man for a crisis -- he forgets that he was ever ill -- he leaves. WE GO WITH HIM. CUT HIM DOWN CORRIDOR QUICKLY. He pauses  outside Preysing's door, uncertain of the rooms, then he  knocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Mr. Preysing -- Oh, Mr. Preysing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He feels there must be a mistake -- he steps back, sees  Flaemmchen's door open next to it. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: He enters. Looks around. Looks through bathroom. Goes qui forward.

dialogues.speaker: PREYSING'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Preysing is still leaning against the table, his mouth is open, he is gaping -- stunned. The two hundred and four p has collapsed and sagged. He is staring, his victim lying a heap upon the floor, very still and quiet. His eyes com around as Kringelein enters. Kringelein crosses, looks down. Touches the Baron's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- the Baron -- the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried to rob me -- he is dead --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My best friend -- poor, Baron --  dead -- just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- We must do something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Yes, the police must be called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- no -- wait -- the man was a  burglar -- he was going to steal my  money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no -- no -- not the Baron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Where is that girl -- she was working  with him -- she enticed me into her  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her room -- oh -- I see, Mr. Preysing --  I understand, Mr. General Director  Preysing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frantically) I can answer for this, it was self- defense -- I can answer for this --  but that girl -- the scandal -- my  wife -- my daughters, you know them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scandal -- we are men -- you --  you could take that affair of the  young lady upon yourself -- take her  and hold your tongue. Then you can  travel -- I'll give you anything --  anything -- she was with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must call the police, your  excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preysing takes him by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much -- how much do you want --  you need money -- you have nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me, Mr. General  Director Pryesing -- worry about  yourself. (he picks up receiver) There has been a murder -- this is  room one sixty-four.

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE ROOM
dialogues.text: Telephone girl plugs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello -- hurry up... hurry up...  someone in one sixty-four says there  has been a murder.

dialogues.speaker: HALL PORTER
dialogues.text: The scene gradually grows intense. Porter calls night man

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here - quick - here -- go to one  sixty-four immediately. (calls back on  telephone) Give me Mr. Rohna -- Rohna the  manager.

dialogues.speaker: ROHNA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Darkened room. Bell ringing. Rohna sits up in bed, turns light, picks up telephone; on his face we see him hear th news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?... murder?... who?... all  right, I'm coming. Wait a minute. (speaks in a monotone) Instruct everyone to use the utmost  tact -- we must have no scandal in  the Grand Hotel. Answer no questions,  I'm coming now -- inform the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he replaces the telephone commences dressing quickly)

dialogues.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Trunks standing around everywhere. Suzette is finishing  packing. Grusinskaya is sitting in front of the mirror in loose night wrap -- she is doing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam should sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done my hair differently -- do  you like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When a lady falls in love she does  her hair differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) In the middle of the night -- those  flowers make me think of a funeral.  Laurels and tube-roses. (she pushes the window  closed, shivers, it  is chilly. She crosses  the room turning out  one of the lights) Oh, think, Suzette -- the Villa and  the sun at Tremezzo -- quiet -- simple --  happy -- we'll have a guest, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes, Madam. And now Madam will sleep.  It is not long 'till the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Suzette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette leaves -- turning out a light. Alone, Grusinskaya goes to the telephone. She raises the  receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello -- can you tell me if Baron  von Gaigern is in his room -- ring  him. (talking to herself) Cherie, I must wake you or you'll  miss the train. (into phone) ...yes... are you ringing, he may be  asleep. (to herself) Cherie, you must get up and fetch me  from my room -- I'm longing for you,  Cherie -- I have not been to sleep --  I kept thinking you would come to  me. (into phone) ...Oh, but he must answer. Ring --  ring -- ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT IN HERE at discretion the:

dialogues.speaker: BARON'S EMPTY ROOM
dialogues.text: Telephone is ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) Cherie, hurry -- hurry -- hurry.  Answer the phone -- what is the  matter. (into phone) Ring him -- ring him. (to herself) Where are you -- where are you,  Cherie? Why don't you answer? (into phone) Well, ring him -- please -- please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music up as we --

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE INTO
dialogues.text: The trees and the milk cart effect and other curious sign of dawn, which we remember after the climax of the first  sequence. Music cold and eerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General early morning bustle and activity. From one van, fruit and vegetables are being unloaded. Fr another, huge hind quarters of beef are being carried in in a monotonous way a baker throws two loaves at a time, another man, from a van backed up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting) Forty-two -- forty-four -- forty-six --  forty-eight -- fifty -- fifty-two --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiters coming to work. A noisy racket. Sandwiched between the bread and butcher vans, is backed hearse. At the moment we come upon it, the men are pausing in the work to glance. The men take off their caps, as; proceede by the hotel detective and others, who will be there, the corpse of the Baron in the basket, used at such time, is  brought out and placed in the hearse, which drives noisil away. A policeman rides with the driver on the box. By this time the man with the bread is counting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred and eight -- one hundred  and ten -- one hundred and twelve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay with him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE INTO
dialogues.text: Shooting onto door - day lighting. A man comes out and signals a black closed limousine, whi pulls forward.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE INTO
dialogues.text: Early morning. Sense of chill and desolation. Some chairs stand on tables. A vacuum cleaner is at work on the carpe Newspaper boys are delivering papers at the news stand. T various shops are slowly being opened, the windows being  cleaned. The general feeling of the beginning of another day. THE CAMERA waits at a distance shooting from door as Prey with a plain clothes man on either side of him, leaves, m towards THE CAMERA. He is grim, his hat is drawn over his eyes. His hands deep in his pockets. When he has passed t

dialogues.speaker: SENF'S DESK
dialogues.text: (the old shot) Meierheim is entering quickly goes through the door. He crosses now to Pimenov. They talk eagerly out of earsh But it is apparent that Meierheim is, as usual, in a hurr Rohna is there too. One of the men carries a telephone st wrapped loosely in paper. But we know it's the telephone  stand. Senf comes on duty, looks around, it is apparent that he late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night clerk has already gone --  you are late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole  night -- there are no words to  describe what my wife suffered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the child isn't coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't  let it interfere with my duty. Any  news here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? -- Who? -- Whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big manufacturer killed Baron  von Gaigern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens. What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man -- that's terrible. He was a  nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems that he was a thief and an  imposter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it -- he was a real  gentleman. I know people... I'm so  tired I can hardly see out of my  eyes. No sleep for two nights and so  many duties and now this killing in  the hotel -- that means a lot of  work. But it's too bad about the  Baron, you always felt better when  he came along -- always friendly --  such an agreeable fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most imposters are --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A number of bellboys march up and form a line. Senf comes from behind the desk and inspects them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in chorus) Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show your hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They show their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to one boy) You have dirty nails -- you little  pig -- you're no good... Caps off! --  Let's see your hair. (Boys take off their  caps) Good -- caps on! (Boys put on their  caps) Where is number seven?... Not here? (to clerk) Take his name -- if he comes late  again today, he's fired. Dismissed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys sit down on the bench. THE CAMERA MOVES TO KRINGELEIN. Kringelein and the police officer move towards the desk i ear shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be sufficient for the  present, sir, you may travel in peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein exits.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR BY ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: As Kringelein emerges from the elevator, Suzette speaking the Floor Clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they've taken him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- it's terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam must not know -- you understand --  Madam must not know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will tell the maids. I cannot answer  for downstairs --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suzette hurries down corridor. By this time Kringelein ha arrived at his door, he opens it.

dialogues.speaker: KRINGELEIN'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Kringelein opens the door and enters. Flaemmchen is looki into space. A lovely picture. Morning light over her hair she is dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- I was thinking -- Poor Baron --  Lying there, his eyes so open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You loved the Baron, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I. He was friendly to me as  no man ever was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps he really was a burglar --  But they don't kill a man for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was in desperate straits. He'd  been trying to raise money all day.  He laughed -- Poor devil! And then a  man like Preysing kills him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (naively) I didn't like Preysing right off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did you have anything to do  with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) Money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, -- money!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand that do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do -- I never knew what  money really meant till I started  spending it. Do you know -- (he is silent a moment) I can hardly believe that anything  so beautiful should come to me from  Preysing -- I'll take care of you.  Will -- will you let me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have a good time with me.  Want to? I've got enough money. Ten  thousand two hundred in my pocketbook.  Three thousand four hundred that I  won. It will last a long time. I can  win more -- we'll travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes -- to Paris? I wanted to go there  always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever you like. Here I'll give  you the money I won, three thousand  four hundred. Later you can have  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I -- I'm ill, Flaemmchen -- It  will not be long -- I'll not last  long. Will you stay with me until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense! We'll find a great doctor,  he'll cure you. They can cure anything  these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe that you will have a  better time with me than you would  with Preysing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes her hands) Do you like me better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man, Mr. Kringelein --  a very good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein straightens, happy, inspired, a smile on his f He assumes in his gestures. Takes the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) When is the next train leaving for  Paris? -- Yes... Get two tickets for  me... and my bill please... and the  lady's -- Miss Flaemm's. (puts down telephone) (to Flaemmchen) We have to hurry let's pack -- we'll  have breakfast on the train.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The figure of Grusinskaya is standing at her door, there no one with her. Suzette steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam, it is Mr. Meierheim -- he is  waiting downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Pimenov? Where is Pimenov? (she looks off.)

dialogues.speaker: FLASH OF PIMENOV
dialogues.text: coming out of the elevator. Grusinskaya hurries down to Pimenov -- they meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathlessly) He will be on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when did he go? How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses and looks in the Baron's room. A maid is ther changing the bedding. The room is unoccupied otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baron von Gaigern has left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? How long ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maid shrugs her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Baron left about half an hour  ago, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- Gru -- come, come -- we'll  lose the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While they are waiting for the elevator Grusinskaya is li a live electric wire. The elevator arrives. They are stepping in.

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY
dialogues.text: General activity. We hear the cry go up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya comes out of the elevator followed by Suzette and Pimenov. Meierheim meets her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along, oh, Madam, come along.  The train will be going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I've got to ask myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use of asking, Gru -- he  is at the train -- He will be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The troupe, the scenery, everything --  all on board, waiting. You have a  rehearsal in Vienna tomorrow morning.  Come, Madam, are you mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya crosses to the desk. She speaks to Senf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen Baron von Gaigern?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (comes over quickly) The Baron is not here, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four minutes past. Please come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Lisaveta, he will be there --  he will be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Madam Grusinskaya's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya, followed by the others, sweeps out towards t door.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR HOTEL
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya emerges, followed by the others. The sunlight hits them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the sun -- it will be sunny in  Tremezzo --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every seat for the opening has been  sold at Vienna. Sold out for three  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know -- I know -- but it will be  sunny in Tremezzo. We'll have a guest  then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Yes, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grusinskaya moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at telephone) Grand Hotel, Head Porter. What?  There's been -- a child born? A boy!  Yes! My child born! It is healthy...  and my wife? Doing well -- all well! (to Clerk) The child has come. They are both  alive. My child...

dialogues.speaker: BY ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: At this moment Kringelein and Flaemmchen are coming out o the elevator, Kringelein is carrying his suitcase. A bellboy attempts to take his bag but Kringelein, still  confused draws his hand with the suitcase away from the  bellboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bag, your Excellency --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing the word 'Excellency' Kringelein goes through a  transformation. He stands and with a flourish hands the  suitcase over to the boy. He is a big man now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very definitely to  boy) Cab please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cab, for his Excellency, Mr.  Kringelein!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Flaemmchen) And now we travel, Flaemmchen...  Glad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Senf) Is the bill ready -- the lady's too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At once. Any forwarding address, Mr.  Kringelein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Paris -- Grand Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know there is a Grand  Hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there must be one in Paris...  They have everything in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bill, Your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kringelein pays and taking Flaemmchen's arm starts to mov away from the desk, General business ad lib of tipping. B line up, making a deep bow. There is almost a triumphant  march as Kringelein and Flaemmchen move towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in chorus) Come again, your Excellency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With head erect, happy smile on his face, Kringelein leav the lobby. Normal activity in lobby, reminding us of open scene. Doctor comes up to desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that Mr. Kringelein leaving?
